docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. authorities' $8.9 billion settlement last month with French bank BNP Paribas for sanctions busting will pay for New York cops to get live computer feeds of street crime and for new carpets in the offices of prosecutors, among many other things.

headline.main: Bank Settlements Create Windfall for U.S., and Wrangling Over How It Is Spent
headline.print_headline: Bank Settlements Create Windfall for U.S., and Wrangling Over How It Is Spent

docs.snippet: U.S. authorities' $8.9 billion settlement last month with French bank BNP Paribas for sanctions busting will pay for New York cops to get live computer feeds of street crime and for new carpets in the offices of prosecutors, among many other things.

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. health insurers will send out about $330 million in rebates to employers and individuals this summer under President Barack Obama's healthcare law, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services said on Thursday.

headline.main: U.S. Health Insurers to Pay $330 Million in Premium Rebates
headline.print_headline: U.S. Health Insurers to Pay $330 Million in Premium Rebates

docs.snippet: U.S. health insurers will send out about $330 million in rebates to employers and individuals this summer under President Barack Obama's healthcare law, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services said on Thursday.

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal court ruling barring some subsidies under the health care law raised the possibility that many of the 4.5 million people who were found eligible for them would drop their coverage.

headline.main: Ruling on Health Care Subsidies Puts Coverage at Risk
headline.print_headline: Court Ruling on Subsidies Risks Loss of Coverage

docs.abstract: Federal appeals court ruling barring federal health insurance subsidies in states that rely on federal insurance exchange raises possibility that many of the 4.5 million people who were found eligible for subsidies will drop their coverage; ruling, along with another appeals court ruling finding opposite in separate case, leaves much unresolved and will be appealed further, even as additional cases challenging subsidies make their way to state-level trial courts.
docs.snippet: A federal court ruling barring some subsidies under the health care law raised the possibility that many of the 4.5 million people who were found eligible for them would drop their coverage.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans pointed to a ruling by an appeals court panel, which said premium subsidies paid to millions of Americans were illegal, as evidence of problems in the law that could not be solved easily.

headline.main: Bolstered by Ruling, Republicans Attack Health Law

docs.snippet: Republicans pointed to a ruling by an appeals court panel, which said premium subsidies paid to millions of Americans were illegal, as evidence of problems in the law that could not be solved easily.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sales of Sovaldi reached $3.5 billion in the second quarter, testifying to the effectiveness of the drug, which can essentially cure over 80 percent of patients with few side effects.

headline.main: Gilead’s Hepatitis C Drug, Sovaldi, Is on Pace to Become a Blockbuster
headline.print_headline: Strong Sales of Hepatitis C Drug Put It on Pace to Become a Blockbuster

docs.abstract: Gilead Sciences announces that sales of hepatitis C drug Sovaldi reached $3.5 billion in second quarter, putting it on track to become one of world's best-selling medicines; sales are an increase from $2.3 billion in first full quarter of sales since drug's approval in 2013, but some insurers and state Medicaid programs are starting to restrict use to those with advanced disease.
docs.snippet: Sales of Sovaldi reached $3.5 billion in the second quarter, testifying to the effectiveness of the drug, which can essentially cure over 80 percent of patients with few side effects.

docs.lead_paragraph: A letter warned members of the orchestra, chorus, stagehands and other workers to prepare for a lockout if no contract deal is reached by next week.

headline.main: Met Opera Prepares to Lock Out Workers
headline.print_headline: Met Opera Prepares to Lock Out Workers

docs.abstract: Metropolitan Opera general manager Peter Gelb warns company's orchestra, chorus, stagehands and other workers to prepare for lockout if no contract is reached within week; several unions bitterly denounce warning, marking urgent new turn in confrontation over planned cuts to pay and benefits.
docs.snippet: A letter warned members of the orchestra, chorus, stagehands and other workers to prepare for a lockout if no contract deal is reached by next week.

keywords.value: International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: William E. Rapfogel, who led the Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty for two decades, was sentenced to at least 3 1/3 years in prison.

headline.main: Rapfogel Is Sentenced for Stealing From His Charity
headline.print_headline: Ex-Director Is Sentenced Over Theft at His Charity

docs.abstract: William E Rapfogel, former director of nonprofit Metropolitan New York Council on Jewish Poverty, accepts plea agreement in conviction for scheming with insurance broker to pad insurance payments and split the surplus; is ordered to pay $3 million remaining balance owed in restitution and is sentenced to 3 1/3 to 10 years in prison.
docs.snippet: William E. Rapfogel, who led the Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty for two decades, was sentenced to at least 3 1/3 years in prison.

keywords.value: Metropolitan New York Council on Jewish Poverty
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: The Affordable Care Act was designed to make health care more affordable and more uniform, but court rulings could deepen the disparities among states.

headline.main: Two Americas on Health Care, and Danger of Further Division
headline.print_headline: Rulings on Health Law Could Deepen U.S. Divide

docs.abstract: The Upshot; Affordable Care Act was designed to help standardize health care and health insurance policy by making it more affordable and more uniform, but series of court rulings on law could deepen disparities among states; if upheld, rulings could leave only richer, Democratic states with federal dollars and broad insurance coverage.
docs.snippet: The Affordable Care Act was designed to make health care more affordable and more uniform, but court rulings could deepen the disparities among states.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: An estimated 10.3 million American adults have gained health coverage since Obamacare enrollment began last October, with the biggest gains among young adults and Hispanics, according to a study published on Wednesday.

headline.main: Over 10 Million U.S. Adults Gain Coverage Under Obamacare: Study
headline.print_headline: Over 10 Million U.S. Adults Gain Coverage Under Obamacare: Study

docs.snippet: An estimated 10.3 million American adults have gained health coverage since Obamacare enrollment began last October, with the biggest gains among young adults and Hispanics, according to a study published on Wednesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study estimates that more than 10 million adults gained health insurance by midyear as the coverage expansion under President Barack Obama's law took hold in much of the country.

headline.main: Study: 10M Have Gained Coverage Through Health Law
headline.print_headline: Study: 10M Have Gained Coverage Through Health Law

docs.snippet: A new study estimates that more than 10 million adults gained health insurance by midyear as the coverage expansion under President Barack Obama's law took hold in much of the country.
